go so um that that's when we made the decision in in september uh 2013.
um so what i'm going to tell you now is the story of how that progressed and i i will tell you this is consider this a
cautionary tale we were a very small shop a very small number of individuals who
were doing this but we had tremendous growth and if you kind of put your mindset in that time
you could imagine that we had opportunities coming out of the woodwork we had things that we wanted to move very quickly on we had new
new airports we wanted to roll out we had new new other types of partners that we wanted
to work with so we needed to get our our stuff migrated very quickly plus we were
paying a lot of money for brick and mortar um and we wanted to be cost efficient
so we we decided that we needed to move very quickly so the first thing we decided to do is to stick our toe in the
water and with aws on the commercial side um so we took our public facing website
which really doesn't collect any information at all and we decided all right let's let's take this and let's put that into commercial and this made
sense for us again we're not collecting any information um it's really kind of a one-way push of a kind of marketing
thing we're rebuilding our website anyway um so we figured this is a good opportunity to to kind of move it it was
we commercial supported a version of the uh operating system that we were comfortable with with cenos 6
so we decided that that was the way it was going to go now it went okay um that
was that went okay but we did run into some issues and and again we were a
young group without a lot of aws awareness and we decided to dive right in um
you know if i had all the time in the world i probably would have done it differently if i had an unlimited budget i probably would have done it
differently but under the circumstances is what happened and we we ran into one one challenge really
with the fact that we used an external dns solution um and we you know because we
forklifted this over effectively didn't work and and with the dynamic nature of ip addresses in aws and so we had to
kind of clue just a solution together early on which is have a effectively a static server that was going to redirect
traffic um but once once we kind of got through that we felt good and we said all right
we declared success there
so thing two now move everything into aws and at this point we we kind of made the decision
and again um we had these massive constraints um we had these constraints
of time and dollars and i didn't want to and i think everyone in this room has probably been
in that case where you know you've started a project and it leaked and leaked and creeped and creeped and creeped and you never fully got there
and then suddenly other stuff came and we just didn't want to expose ourselves to that trap so
we basically said that we are going to shut down our old data center in three months we give ourselves three months
and we said you know no matter what happens we're flipping the switch off so we we really need to get everything over
um again there are people in the company who hate me for for you know for pushing that but um
um anyway they everyone survived um which is which is the happy end of the story
um but this was that we ran into a lot more challenges here and this is where the cautionary tale part comes in um we
we decided to make a move to uh aws version of linux
because you know if we're if we're making the move to aws we might as well go all in and so we might as well be on
on the natively supported operating system so um there were there were some challenges there and you
know it took it took a lot more to get our application to feel very comfortable in that environment
the other thing to be aware of is again we were in this old brick and mortar data center with really big servers and
you know it's like a budget if you have a really big budget you'll find a way to use it and the software found a way to
use up all the resources on those servers so when we migrated those over um and effectively did a forklift over
into govcloud just to get it done the only instances we could run on were
xl instances and and that is um expensive um and and we realized that we
also lost a lot of our redundancy um a lot of the old legacy code was very bespoke to
that environment it was it was very specific to that environment and just forklifting it over and expecting
everything to work as is was um well it just didn't it didn't didn't
happen so we actually had to make the decision in order to get there in that three month period we had to um effectively
cut our our failover which meant that we just had to have engineers and help desk um sitting
there looking at terminals 24 7 until we figured that out but
we made the conscious decision early on that if there was going to be any pain we were going to feel the pain ourselves
because then we'd be incentivized to fix the pain right so throughout this whole migration um i
will say that our our members never felt it um there was no downtime at all um
again everyone in engineering group it clear hated me but um you know pain is temporary and and they
survived the last thing is
if if you understand clear when you go into the airports there are kiosks there and there are people who work at these kiosks and they're there
for in enrollment so when you go in you enroll with your passport and driver's license and we capture your biometrics
and we do an identity quiz there's verification kiosks where you go into the lane and you put your
finger down and scan your boarding pass and you go through all of those kiosks are either on a
shared or individual router and each one of those routers has its own vpn connection back to um
back to aws in this case in govcloud so this is really where having a partner
like cloudnexa came in tremendously well i mean obviously they helped us with the migration they helped us get comfortable
and unders and helped us understand how to monitor not just our usage but how to monitor our application and they
introduced us to tools like app dynamics and helped us implement app dynamics which gave us a lot of intelligence as
to what was going on but they also helped us work with aws to make sure that we could have
the number of vpcs and and the number of vpns that we needed to to tie those um
those kiosks back to us so they they worked really as a great extended uh member of our
engineering team um so the good news is we got it done in
three months and in february um we were over and we shut the lights off in our old data center um and and again this is
just a quote that i was trying to throw in that's one of my favorite quotes so um thank you for reading that
so february we're in and everything is up and running and we turned off the old data center which is great
but we are still hugely not optimized so we're running on
a ton of servers really big servers we don't have great monitoring we don't have great failback
except for manual intervention and we're losing a lot of sleep
we can only do deployments in the middle of the night because we can't do things down so we lost all of our agility in a
development cycle there there was a lot of concern there so we needed to move quickly so really
the next thing we had to do is was optimize for aws and we spent a good deal of time doing this
so we had to first focus on our code base um we had to go into our our code
base and make it more efficient so we ended up having thousands of of threads running in our existing code and
our legacy code base um under under exp inspection and again um appdynamics was
a great tool to help us realize that and it helped us focus in on where the bottlenecks were and where where these
threads were leaking from and how to get in there and we spent a lot of time just going in there and knocking those down
and that gave us the opportunity to reduce the size of the servers that we're running on right
next thing we did was we we had to focus on load balancing load balancing obviously is important
because something goes down you want to not have any interruption service but it also allows us to deploy
mid-day so you could bring down you could bring down a node update it you know bring it up the load
balancer update it bring it back on the load down so bring something else down lets you do this intraday so we're not
having sleepy engineers during the day because they're doing all their deployments at nighttime
and then we started taking advantage of a lot of the services that did that were offered
by aws so by moving into rds for example we got to get rid of some servers and we
got to move both our kind of data analytics platform and our transactional platform into rds
and that saved us a lot of time it it it saved us a lot of money
and it was less servers for us to manage um we we we moved into amazon storage
solution obviously same thing we had everything locally on the servers and this was a more uh this is a better way
to save money and and just be more compliant with them with
aws monitoring and obviously getting more into security
groups so we no longer had um you know we i no longer needed a dedicated person to sit
there and and do hardcore firewall work and and could reallocate them to come
more heady stuff so what we're able to achieve through
through that process up until now is you know we can now do deployments today
we now have lots of redundancy we can scale up and scale down all the goodness of the cloud and we started realizing
that again it took us a long time to realize that um you know we were three months of pain to get over to aws but it
was our pain um it took us another three four months to start realizing the value of some of these optimizations but we
were able to realize it and it was uh it was a tremendous investment but but we got there
so the next things that we're looking at i still consider us very much of a novice aws user and again
partnering with um with cloud nexa and some of the other providers that they bring to the table
is is helping us um but there's a lot that we need um to take advantage of from aws and we still plan on taking
advantage of so we're looking at route 53 instead of using our external dns
platform bringing it in-house and being more kind of aws esque in that capacity looking at
elastic bean stock and commercial i think you know i think the consensus
is we won't really see elastic bean stock in govcloud um just because of the nature of of govcloud and and
the desire not to get too deep into what's going on there it's going to be very hard for elastic bean stock to work
there but there there are some other things that we're looking at in govcloud that i'll get to and obviously continued
managed growth through cloud nexus so we're using their vnoc to do things like
scheduling our processes our dev and qa processes so that we could take them down
overnight and not have to pay for them we do better cost analysis we could start seeing how we're trending to
budget and making sure that we're being smart about how we're allocating resources
we're using them for snapshots to do our backups of all of our environments
and we've just recently upgraded to their premium managed services which i don't know i think they announced it
they wouldn't let me talk about it if they didn't announce it so i'm guessing yes um so it's a partnership with app
dynamics sumo logic and trend micro um and um it's been great i mean we

out in the wild lots of logs so being able to consolidate all that and very quickly
uh filter and um look for patterns um
really helpful and obviously trend micro from a security perspective because you know with security is is really the
business that we're in
so learnings um again you know i think of us as a cautionary tale you know we went
in eyes wide open in our decision to um you know burn the ships behind us
commit to aws um you know i think they're if if we could go back in time now that we're living in
the future it's easy to go back and say oh these are the things we would have done differently um

obviously and i think this goes with that saying but one of those um
one of the things that was a real gotcha was that govcloud which we have our entire production environment in does

there and that was something that we had to build i don't know if that's going to change i can't imagine that's going to change
very much so that was a tremendous kind of takeaway
security groups are very different from firewalls we learned a lot about security groups we realized that on the plus side you
know it's much easier to implement but it's not as granular as firewalls and
that was you know something that we know but until you get in there and start playing with it
you don't realize what those differences really are and then we have a pretty big you know
